resources.string: White Patches In Back of Throat
Neck Stiffness (inability to touch chin to neck)
How long have your symptoms been present?
Less Than or Equal To 7 Days
Please select the appropriate range for your fever.
What color is your nasal discharge?
Please select any of the pre-existing conditions that apply to you.
Are you sure the selections you have made are correct?
The common cold includes nasal congestion, runny nose (discharge can be clear or yellow-green), sore throat, cough, fatigue, low grade fever, sneezing and headache.
The common cold lasts from 3-10 days and longer in smokers.
The common cold is differentiated from viral or allergic nasal inflammation by the presence of sore throat and cough.
The common cold can be differentiated from bacterial tonsillitis (pharyngitis or tonsil infection) by the presence of runny nose and nasal congestion.
No antibiotics are needed to treat the common cold.

Pharyngitis (infection of the throat and glands) symptoms include sore throat, fever, fatigue, swollen neck glands, and with or without white patches in the back of the throat. Usually pharyngitis requires antibiotics.
If there is no fever but there is a cough with pharyngitis symptoms, no antibiotics are needed.
The common cold can cause and lead to sinusitis, lower respiratory tract infection, asthma exacerbation and ear infections.
Acute sinusitis includes symptoms of facial pain, clear or yellow-green nasal discharge, nasal obstruction.
The most common cause of acute sinusitis is viral infections. Therefore no antibiotics are recommended unless patient has fever greater than or equal to 102 or other risk factors.
Acute viral sinusitis is expected to improve within 10 days without the use of antibiotics. Nasal discharge starts clear in viral sinusitis but may turn yellow-green later in the illness.
Acute bacterial sinusitis lasts longer than 10 days, causes high fevers (>102), and nasal discharge is yellow-green within the first 3 days of illness.
Acute bronchitis includes cough, sputum (mucous from respiratory tract) and lasts at least 5 days. Wheezing and shortness of breath are also symptoms of acute bronchitis.
Influenza symptoms include high fever, cough, headache, muscle and body aches. Antivirals are recommended to treat influenza.
Pertussis is similar to the common cold but has prolonged coughing and will require antibiotics.
The majority of upper respiratory infections are transmitted by hand contact. Viruses remain alive on human skin for 2 hours. Therefore hand washing is important to prevent the spread of disease.
Antibiotics are not indicated for cold, flu, bronchitis, most coughs, most sore throats, some ear infections, some sinus infections, and stomach flu.
Unnecessary use of antibiotics creates resistant bacteria/superbugs that are hard to treat and cause approximately 23,000 per year in the U.S.
Analgesics for headache, body aches, muscle and joint aches.
A combination product containing an antihistamine and decongestant combination or intranasal/inhalation cromolyn may help with nasal symptoms.
Application of topical saline to nasal cavity will temporarily help with nasal congestion.
Cough may be treated with dextromethorphan.
Stay well hydrated and ingest warm fluids.
